byline.contributor: Hisako Ueno contributed reporting from Tokyo, and Andrew Jacobs from Beijing.

abstract: Japanese Prime Min Shinzo Abe, despite widespread public opposition and demonstrations, garners critical vote in Parliament for law granting Japan's military limited ability to fight abroad for first time since World War II; vote comes after months of rancorous debate in society that has practiced pacifism to atone for wartime aggression.
lead_paragraph: The lawmakers endorsed Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s legislation despite broad public opposition and the largest demonstrations in three years.

headline.main: Japan Moves to Allow Military Combat for First Time in 70 Years
headline.print_headline: Japan Moves to Allow Military Combat for First Time in 70 Years

snippet: The lawmakers endorsed Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s legislation despite broad public opposition and the largest demonstrations in three years.
